title: SoC THEATRE 244-1-21 The Development of Contemporary Theatre

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
his is the first in a two-class sequence that marches through theatre history in Europe and the United States from the 1870s to the end of World War II in 1945. We will read writers associated with the rise of such influential movements as naturalism (Henrik Ibsen), surrealism (Jean Cocteau), and expressionism (Georg Kaiser). Classes in theatre and literary history sometimes tend to foreground formal innovation at the expense of other concerns. To counteract this, even as we study changes in theatrical forms, we will spend over half of our time reading texts written by women and writers of color who sometimes used the new forms, or who sometimes chose to write in modes, such as melodrama or folk theatre, from which theatrical elites tended to distance themselves. We will be looking for a balanced overview of what was going on during this incredibly fertile period of theatre history. To do this we will not only read plays by writers of many backgrounds, we will also examine readings from the political theory, psychology, and philosophy of the period.

Students will have homework assignments, reading quizzes, two 3-4 page essays, and one 8-10 page essay.
